title: Though, although, even though, even if, in spite of or despite

questions.question: I enjoyed the party ................................. having a headache.
questions.description: Both despite and in spite of are possible here. They are both prepositions and can be followed by a noun or an -ing form. Though and although are conjunctions and should be followed by clauses.

questions.question: .......................... he was there, he did not acknowledge my presence.
questions.description: Though and although are conjunctions and should be followed by clauses. In spite of and despite are prepositions.

questions.question: ......................... she was angry, she said nothing.
questions.description: Though and although are conjunctions and need to be followed by clauses.
answers: Either in spite of or despite

questions.question: She passed her exam ............................ having a bad teacher.
questions.description: Despite is a preposition and can be followed by a noun or -ing form. In spite is not a preposition. The correct expression is in spite of.

questions.question: ......................... the train was late, I managed to arrive on time.
questions.description: Even though refers to the past even if refers to the future.

questions.question: I will do it ........................... it kills me.
questions.description: Even if refers to the future. Even though refers to the past.

questions.question: ............................. his disability, he works very hard.
questions.description: The expressions though, although, even though and even if are all conjunctions and should be followed by a clause. In spite of is a preposition. It is followed by a noun or ing form.

questions.question: .................................... I didn't understand a word, I kept smiling.
questions.description: Though and even though have similar meanings. Even though is more emphatic.

questions.question: The strongest argument, ............................., is political not economic.
questions.description: Though can be used as an adverb and it means 'however'. Even though and although cannot be used with this meaning.

questions.question: ............................ I don't agree with his views, I think he is honest.
questions.description: Though, although and even though have the same meaning. Even though is more emphatic than though or although.

questions.question: .............................. she worked very hard, she didn't get the promotion.
questions.description: Despite is a preposition and cannot be followed by a clause. Even if refers to the future.

questions.question: ............................... of performing well in the interview, she didn't get the job.
questions.description: Even if and even though are conjunctions followed by clauses.
